week3.practice2_html:
What it is

The Popeye Protocol helps you rebuild your iron stores naturally through food and smarter pairings, so your follicles finally have the oxygen and nutrients they need to restart healthy growth.

Why this practice matters for you now

Julia, youâ€™re in the stabilization phase â€” shedding has steadied, yet regrowth hasnâ€™t kicked in because your follicles are still catching up from past low iron. This step is your big domino: restoring iron fully now sets the stage for early 2026 regrowth. Since nutrition is your main driver, even small, steady boosts in dietary iron can shorten that waiting window.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Anchor iron-rich foods daily. Include one â€œiron heroâ€ meal a day â€” e.g., lentil stew, beef strips, tofu with spinach, or fortified oats.
  2. Add vitaminâ€¯C companions. Pair your iron meal with fresh fruit, bell peppers, or lemon juice to double absorption naturally.
  3. Keep blockers in check. Leave tea, coffee, or calcium-rich foods at least an hour away from your iron meal to avoid interference.
  4. Use your plate as a tracker. Each day, pause after dinner and note if you hit both an iron and a vitaminâ€¯C source â€” that quick check-in builds momentum.

week3.practice3_html:
What it is

Calm Your Scalp and Body is a quick reset for the moments when worry about hair loss or life in general spikes. Itâ€™s a way to quiet your nerves so your body slips out of â€œfight or flightâ€ and your follicles get the calm signal they need to keep growing.

Why this practice matters for you now

Julia, youâ€™re in the stabilization phase â€” shedding has steadied, but new growth hasnâ€™t shown yet. After months of lowâ€‘iron stress on your body, any surge of anxiety can still tell your scalp youâ€™re unsafe. This practice is your big domino right now: calming your system helps your follicles shift from recovery mode toward steady regrowth as early as February. Think of it as teaching your scalp that the danger has passed.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Pause the spiral. When you feel your chest tighten or your mind race about shedding, stop what youâ€™re doing and place both hands over your scalp for one breath.
  2. Ground through your senses. Name out loud: 3 things you see, 2 things you hear, 1 thing you can touch. This brings your brain back into the present moment.
  3. Breathe low and slow. Inhale through your nose for 4 counts, exhale through your mouth for 6. Repeat for one minute while gently massaging your scalp with your fingertips.
  4. Redirect. Once calmer, do one small nourishing act â€” refill your water, step outside for light, or plan your next proteinâ€‘rich meal.
  5. Anchor it daily. Practice this at least once a day, not just when stressed, so your nervous system learns calm as its baseline.

What to look for

  • Early wins: Feeling more relaxed within 2â€“3 minutes; fewer stressâ€‘induced scalp tingles or tightness; steadier energy across the afternoon.
  • Watch-outs: Emotional eating right after stress spikes â€” try doing the 4â€‘6 breath first, then decide if youâ€™re truly hungry.
  • Consistency builds momentum â€” one calm moment at a time. ğŸŒ±
